Description: Greek female terracotta figure. Head broken off just below the chin. Modelled facial features, hair in two bulbous strands above forehead, from central parting, then hanging down the sides. Top of head broken off. Mould-made and solid. Traces of white coating in a few places. Pale orange fine clay, not obviously micaceous, possibly Attic?
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Bolton Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallels of Classical Greek terracottas women standing or sitting occur across the Greek world. Examples found in Rhodes and Attica dated to the mid 5th century BC (see Higgins 1964, no. 210, 211, 212, 213, 220, 222, 669). Naukratis parallels in Bolton Museum (1886.31.32, 1911.44.25) and copy in local Egyptian clay in Cambridge Museum Classical Archaeology (NA342).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.394) (Phase 1)
